titlestmt.author: Rachel Mahre

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: New York Metro Area Postal Union Oral History

physdesc.extent: in 2 flat boxes and 1 letter manuscript box

did.abstract: This collection consists of oral history interviews of 15 retired officers or activists of the New York Metro Area Postal Union, as well as interview transcripts. The interviews cover the topics of postal service working conditions, the evolution of the Union and its leadership, the Local 10, the National Federation of Post Office Clerks, the organization of Postal Union of Manhattan – Bronx Clerks, National Postal Clerks Union, and the national postal strike of 1970. The collection also contains an extensive interview with Morris Biller, President of the union from 1959-80, when he became president of the national union.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Dana Schechter on behalf of Cornell University in circa 1989. The accession number associated with this gift is 1980.021.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged alphabetically by the interviewee's last name.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The New York Area Postal Union represents over 21,000 postal clerks, motor vehicle operators, maintenance, and mail handlers in New York and New Jersey. The local resulted from the 1958 secession of officers and members of Local 10, National Federation of Post Office Clerks, an organization dating back to 1901. The secessionists favored an industrial organization that would include all postal crafts.

Barbara Wertheimer, labor educator at Cornell NYSSILR's New York Labor Extension, conceived of an oral history project utilizing union retiree groups to document workers' contributions to New York City. The study of the New York Metro Postal Workers began in 1976 with a small grant under the direction of Dana Schecter. For two years, Schecter met with a group of retired postal workers, trained them in oral history techniques, and set them to the task of the interviewing. Schecter donated the tapes and transcripts to the Wagner Archives in 1980.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; New York Metro Area Postal Union Oral History; OH 003; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was arranged and described by an archivist in December, 2022.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For more materials related to the New York Metro Area Postal Union, see:
New York Metro Area Postal Union Collection Records (WAG.103),
Josie McMillian's oral history interview in the New Yorkers at Work Oral History Collection (OH.001).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barbara Wertheimer, labor educator at Cornell NYSSILR's New York Labor Extension, conceived of an oral history project utilizing union retiree groups to document workers' contributions to New York City. The study of the New York Metro Postal Workers began in 1976 with a small grant under the direction of Dana Schecter. For two years, Schecter met with a group of retired postal workers, trained them in oral history techniques, and set them to the task of the interviewing. Schecter donated the tapes and transcripts to the Wagner Archives in 1980.

This collection consists of oral history interviews of 15 retired officers or activists of the New York Metro Area Postal Union, as well as transcripts of each of the interviews. The interviews cover the topics of postal service working conditions, the evolution of the Union and its leadership, the Local 10, the National Federation of Post Office Clerks, the organization of Postal Union of Manhattan – Bronx Clerks, National Postal Clerks Union, and the national postal strike of 1970. The collection also contains an extensive interview with Morris Biller, President of the union from 1959-80, when he became president of the national union.
All interviews have master recordings (stored in Box 2) and user access copies (stored in Box 3). All interviews have paper transcripts with the exception of Leo Goodwin and Otto Gottlieb.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Cornell University, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Biller was President of New York Area Postal Union of the American Postal Workers, AFL-CIO, as well as Regional Coordinator for the Northeast Region of the American Workers' Postal Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Epstein discusses work experiences, McCarthyism and the Union in the 1930s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Goldberg discusses finance insurance funds, substition work, and work inequities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kamish was a delegate addressing poor working conditions; he discusses the Summerfield suspension and the 1958 break from AFL-CIO.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kaye was a supervisor who was with the postal service from 1913-1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mandell discusses being a woman on the job, GPO incoming mail, and general changes in the work environment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elsie Resnick discusses sexism at work, working conditions, GPO incoming mail, Sick Aid, and the 1970 strike.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert Resnick discusses supervisor negligence, GPO incoming mail, and the 1970 strike.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rosner was Secretary-Treasurer of New York Metro Postal Workers; he discusses the credit union, politics and finances, and dangers of the job.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ryland discusses racism, the lengthy fight to be allowed to sit on the job, case stories, and the 1969 Contsitution Convention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Salk discusses early labor conditions, his rise to leadership, and Dave Edelson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group interview discusses the break from AFL-CIO and the fight to enforce exams for managers, among other topics.
